This is the third individual therapy session with Anna. She continues to struggle with confronting her boyfriend, Jake, about his infidelity, citing fear and uncertainty about what comes next. However, Anna is beginning to reflect on the need to focus on herself, considering steps like reconnecting with hobbies and setting personal boundaries. The session centers around Anna’s fear of being alone, her attachment to the life she has built with Jake, and the possibility of rediscovering her independence. The therapist helps Anna explore the idea of creating space for herself before making any decisions about the relationship.
"Welcome back, Anna. How have things been since our last session? Have you had more time to think about what we discussed?"

[sighs] "I’ve been thinking a lot, actually. It’s been…overwhelming, to be honest. I still haven’t confronted Jake. Every time I get close to bringing it up, I panic. But I’ve also been reflecting on what you said last time about focusing on myself. That part stuck with me."
"I’m glad that resonated with you. It sounds like you’re still working through a lot of emotions. What’s been stopping you from confronting Jake?"

"It’s just…fear. The more I think about it, the more I wonder if I’m ready to face the reality of what comes after. What if he denies it? Or what if he admits it, but I can’t forgive him? And then what? I feel paralyzed."
"That fear of the unknown is powerful, especially when the outcome feels so uncertain. You mentioned feeling paralyzed—what do you think would help you feel more prepared to confront him?"

"I don’t know. Maybe if I felt more confident in what I want? Right now, I feel like I’m just reacting to my emotions. One minute, I’m angry and ready to leave, and the next, I’m scared and just want things to go back to normal. I’m not sure what I even want anymore."
"It’s understandable to feel torn when the emotions are so intense and conflicting. What would it look like for you to explore what you really want, outside of the fear and confusion?"

[pauses, thinking] "I guess it would mean taking a step back and focusing on myself, like we talked about. Maybe I’ve been so wrapped up in the relationship and what Jake did that I haven’t given myself the space to figure out what I need. But it’s hard. Every time I think about leaving, I get scared of being alone."
"That fear of being alone seems to be a big part of what’s keeping you in this state of limbo. What do you think being alone would mean for you?"

"I guess it would mean starting over. Rebuilding my life without Jake. We’ve built so much together—the apartment, our routines—and the thought of losing all that is terrifying. It feels like I’d be losing part of myself."

"It sounds like there’s a lot of attachment to the life you’ve built together, and that’s completely valid. But you also mentioned last time that starting over could be an opportunity to reconnect with yourself. How does that idea feel to you now?"

[smiles slightly] "It still feels…liberating in a way. I’ve been thinking about it more, and I realized that I haven’t really been living for myself lately. Everything has revolved around Jake and the relationship, and I’ve kind of lost touch with my own needs. Starting over might give me a chance to figure out who I am again."

"That’s a powerful realization. Reclaiming your sense of self could be an important part of your healing process, whether you choose to stay in the relationship or not. What steps do you think you could take to start focusing more on yourself, even before making any decisions about the relationship?"

"I’ve been thinking about that too. I used to love photography, but I haven’t picked up my camera in months. I think I want to start doing that again, just for me. And I’ve also been thinking about setting some boundaries with Jake—giving myself some space to breathe, you know?"

"Those sound like great steps. Photography could be a way for you to reconnect with something that brings you joy, and setting boundaries could help you create space to focus on your own needs. How do you think Jake would respond if you started setting those boundaries?"

"I’m not sure. He’s been acting like everything is fine, like nothing has changed. But I’ve been distant, and I think he’s starting to notice. I haven’t told him why, of course, but I feel like if I start pulling away more, he might start asking questions."
"It’s possible that he’ll notice the changes, especially if you start focusing more on yourself. How do you feel about having that conversation with him, about needing space or setting boundaries?"

"Honestly, I’m scared. I don’t want him to think I’m giving up on us, but at the same time, I need to take care of myself. Maybe it’s time to start being honest with him about what I need, even if I’m not ready to confront him about the cheating yet."

"That could be a good first step—expressing what you need for yourself, without necessarily diving into the infidelity yet. It gives you a chance to take control of the situation and create space for yourself, without feeling rushed into a decision. How do you think that conversation might go?"

"I don’t know. I feel like I’m always tiptoeing around him, trying not to rock the boat. But I also know that I can’t keep doing that. I need to be honest about what I need, even if it’s uncomfortable."
"It sounds like you’re recognizing the importance of standing up for your own needs, even if it feels risky. What do you think is the biggest obstacle to having that conversation?"

"I think it’s fear of rejection. What if he doesn’t care? What if he just brushes it off or gets defensive? I’m scared that if I tell him I need space, he’ll pull away completely, and then I’ll feel even more alone."

"That fear of rejection is understandable, especially when the relationship feels so fragile. But setting boundaries is about protecting your own well-being, and it’s okay if he doesn’t respond perfectly. What’s important is that you’re taking care of yourself. How would it feel to approach this conversation with the mindset that you’re prioritizing your own needs, regardless of how he reacts?"

[pauses, reflecting] "It would feel empowering, I think. Like I’m taking control for the first time in a while. But it’s scary too. I’ve spent so much time putting his needs first, I don’t know what it looks like to put myself first."

"It’s a big shift, and it’s okay to feel scared. But the fact that you’re even considering this step shows that you’re ready to start prioritizing yourself. It’s a process, and it doesn’t have to happen all at once. What do you think would be the first small step you could take toward putting yourself first?"

"I think the first step would be having that conversation. Telling him that I need space, that I need time to focus on myself. Even if I don’t bring up the cheating yet, I think that would be a way to start reclaiming some control."

"That sounds like a meaningful first step. It’s about asserting your needs without feeling the pressure to resolve everything at once. How do you feel about preparing for that conversation? Is there anything you’d like to explore before having it?"

[thinking deeply] "I think I need to figure out exactly what I want to say. I don’t want it to turn into a fight or for him to think I’m pushing him away completely. Maybe I could start by explaining that I’ve been feeling overwhelmed and that I need some time to focus on myself."

"That sounds like a thoughtful approach. Framing it around your need to focus on yourself can help prevent it from feeling like an attack. Would it help to practice what you want to say, or to outline your thoughts before the conversation?"

"Yeah, I think that would help. I’ve been so in my head about it, I haven’t really thought about how to say it. Maybe if I can get my thoughts clear, I’ll feel more confident going into the conversation."

"We can definitely work through that. If you’d like, we could practice what you might say here, or we can talk about how to prepare. The goal is to help you feel as grounded and confident as possible before having the conversation."
"That would be great. I think practicing it might make it feel less intimidating."
"Okay, let’s start by imagining you’re sitting down with Jake. How would you begin the conversation?"

[pauses, takes a deep breath] "I guess I would start by saying something like, ‘I’ve been feeling overwhelmed lately, and I’ve realized that I need some space to focus on myself. It’s not about pushing you away, but I just need time to figure things out for myself.’ Does that sound okay?"

"That sounds like a very clear and respectful way to express your needs. It communicates that this is about your own well-being, rather than an attack on the relationship. How does it feel to say it out loud?"
"It feels…good, actually. A little scary, but good. I think I can do this."

"I’m glad to hear that. You’ve already taken a huge step by getting to this point, and it sounds like you’re ready to start prioritizing yourself in a way that feels empowering. How are you feeling as we wrap up today’s session?"
"I feel more confident, like I finally have a plan. I’m still nervous, but I know I need to do this for myself. I’m ready to have that conversation."

"You’re making incredible progress, Anna. It’s clear that you’re committed to this journey of self-discovery and growth. We’ll continue to support you as you take these next steps, and I’m confident that you’ll find the clarity and strength you’re looking for. I’ll see you next week, and we’ll talk about how it went."
"Thanks. See you next week."

This is the fourth individual therapy session with Anna. She shares that she had a conversation with Jake about needing space, though she hasn’t confronted him about the cheating yet. The session focuses on Anna’s feelings of empowerment from setting boundaries, though she still feels guilty and conflicted. Anna expresses both relief and fear of the unknown as she starts to prioritize herself. The therapist helps Anna explore ways to reconnect with her independence through hobbies, social activities, and self-care, while encouraging her to stay grounded in her own needs, regardless of Jake’s reactions.
"Welcome back, Anna. How are you feeling today? Were you able to have that conversation with Jake?"

[takes a deep breath] "Yeah…I did. It was hard, but I finally had the conversation. I told him that I’ve been feeling overwhelmed and that I needed some space to focus on myself. I didn’t bring up the cheating yet, but just telling him I needed space was a big step for me."
"That’s a huge step, Anna. How did the conversation go? What was Jake’s reaction?"

"He was surprised, to say the least. At first, he didn’t really get it—he asked if I was mad at him or if he did something wrong. I tried to explain that it wasn’t about him, but about me needing time to figure things out. He was quiet after that, like he didn’t know what to say. But he didn’t get defensive, which I was worried about."
"It sounds like Jake’s response was more neutral than you expected, and it’s good that he didn’t become defensive. How did it feel for you to express what you needed in that moment?"

[pauses, reflecting] "It felt strange at first, like I was doing something wrong by asking for space. But as I kept talking, it started to feel more empowering. For the first time in a long time, I felt like I was prioritizing myself instead of tiptoeing around him or the relationship."
"That’s an important shift—to feel empowered and recognize that you’re allowed to prioritize yourself. How did things feel between you and Jake after the conversation? Did anything change?"

"There was definitely some tension afterward. He didn’t say much after I told him I needed space, and he’s been acting a bit distant since then. I think he’s confused, like he doesn’t know how to react. Part of me feels guilty for making him feel that way, but another part of me knows that I needed to do this for myself."

"It’s natural to feel some guilt, especially when you’re breaking out of old patterns and setting boundaries for the first time. But it’s also important to remember that your needs matter, and it sounds like you’re beginning to make space for those needs in a way you haven’t before. How are you feeling now that you’ve taken this step?"

"Relieved, mostly. It’s like I’ve been carrying this weight for so long, and now that I’ve finally said something, I feel lighter. But there’s still this underlying fear—like I’m waiting for the other shoe to drop. I still haven’t told him about the cheating, and it’s eating away at me."

"That’s completely understandable. It sounds like you’re feeling a mix of relief from setting boundaries, but also the weight of holding onto the secret about the cheating. What’s been holding you back from bringing it up?"

[sighs heavily] "I think it’s fear of how he’ll react. I keep going over it in my head—what if he denies it? What if he tries to turn it around on me or says it was just a mistake? And then there’s the fear of what comes after. If I bring it up, I know there’s no going back. It’ll change everything."

"That fear of what comes next is understandable. Once you confront him, it opens up a whole new set of challenges, and it sounds like you’re not sure if you’re ready for that. What do you think would help you feel more prepared to have that conversation?"

[pauses, thinking deeply] "I think…I need to feel more grounded in my decision. Right now, I’m still not sure what I want. Part of me thinks that if he’s really sorry, maybe we can work through it. But another part of me wonders if I’ll ever be able to trust him again. I’m scared of making the wrong decision."

"It sounds like you’re feeling torn between wanting to give him a chance and the fear that the trust might be too damaged to repair. What do you think would make you feel more certain about whether you want to stay in the relationship or not?"

"I think I need to know if he’s really willing to work on things. If he just brushes it off or tries to make excuses, I don’t think I could stay. But if he takes responsibility and shows that he’s committed to fixing things, maybe there’s a chance. But honestly…I don’t even know if that would be enough."

"It sounds like there’s a lot of uncertainty around what would be enough for you to feel like you could rebuild the relationship. That’s completely valid—trust is something that takes time to rebuild, and it’s okay if you’re not sure yet whether that’s something you want to pursue. Have you thought about what it would mean for you if you decided to leave the relationship?"

"I have, and it’s terrifying. The idea of starting over at 32, of being single again…it scares me. But at the same time, I’ve been thinking a lot about what we’ve talked about—about focusing on myself and finding out who I am outside of this relationship. Part of me feels like leaving would give me a chance to do that. But then I get scared of being alone."

"That fear of being alone is something we’ve touched on before, and it’s a very real and valid fear. But you’re also recognizing that there could be an opportunity for growth and self-discovery if you were to move forward on your own. How does that idea sit with you now?"

[pauses, reflecting] "It feels…less scary than it did before. The more I think about it, the more I realize that I’ve lost myself in this relationship. I used to be so independent, and now I feel like I’ve become dependent on Jake in ways I didn’t even realize. Maybe being on my own would give me a chance to rediscover that independence."

"It sounds like you’re starting to see that independence as a possibility, rather than something to fear. Reconnecting with yourself and your independence could be an important part of your healing process, whether you decide to stay or leave. What steps do you think you could take to start exploring that independence now, even while you’re still in this uncertain space?"

"I’ve been thinking about that, actually. I want to start doing things on my own again—like going out with friends or pursuing hobbies without feeling guilty. I used to love photography, and I want to pick that up again. I also want to spend more time on myself, like going for walks or journaling. Just doing things that make me feel grounded."

"Those sound like wonderful steps toward reconnecting with yourself and your independence. Photography, journaling, spending time with friends—those are all ways to nurture yourself and create space for your own growth. How do you think Jake will respond to you spending more time focusing on yourself?"

"I’m not sure. He’s already been distant since I told him I needed space, so I don’t know how he’ll take it if I start doing more things on my own. Part of me feels like he might think I’m pulling away from him completely. But I also know that I can’t keep living the way I’ve been living—putting his needs first all the time."

"It sounds like you’re ready to prioritize yourself, even if it creates some tension in the relationship. It’s important to remember that your well-being comes first, and that it’s okay to create space for yourself. How would it feel to focus on your own needs, regardless of how Jake responds?"

"It feels empowering, but also a little scary. I’m so used to putting his needs before mine that it feels like I’m doing something wrong by focusing on myself. But I know that’s not true—I know I need to take care of myself. It’s just hard to break out of that mindset."

"Breaking out of old patterns can be challenging, especially when you’ve been in the habit of putting someone else’s needs first for so long. But you’re already taking steps toward prioritizing yourself, and that’s a huge shift. What do you think would help you stay focused on your own growth, even when it feels difficult?"

"I think I need to keep reminding myself why I’m doing this—that it’s for me, not to hurt Jake or push him away. Maybe if I set small goals for myself, like spending more time with friends or taking a photography class, it’ll help me stay focused on what I need."

"Setting small, achievable goals sounds like a great way to stay connected to your own needs. It gives you something tangible to work toward and helps you stay grounded in your growth. How are you feeling now that you’ve had some time to reflect on these changes?"

"I’m feeling more sure of myself, I think. I still have a lot to figure out, but I’m starting to see that I don’t have to rush into any decisions. I can take my time and focus on myself first, and the rest will follow."

"That’s a very healthy perspective, Anna. You’re giving yourself the time and space you need to explore what feels right for you, and that’s a powerful step toward healing. We’ll continue to support you as you take these next steps, and I’m confident that you’ll find clarity as you move forward. How are you feeling as we wrap up today’s session?"

"I feel more at peace, actually. It helps to know that I can take things one step at a time, and that I don’t have to figure everything out all at once. I’m ready to start focusing more on myself and see where that leads."

"You’re doing incredible work, and it’s clear that you’re committed to your own growth and healing. We’ll continue to support you in this journey, and I look forward to hearing how things progress. I’ll see you next week."
"Thanks. See you next week."

This is the fifth therapy session with Anna. She shares that she has been focusing more on herself, spending time with friends and reconnecting with her photography. Anna mentions feeling less dependent on Jake and acknowledges that she’s starting to realize she can be okay on her own. However, she is still hesitant to confront Jake about the cheating and expresses fear of how the conversation will change their relationship. The session focuses on preparing for this difficult conversation and helping Anna clarify what she needs from Jake to move forward.
"Welcome back, Anna. How have you been feeling since our last session? Have you been able to focus more on yourself like we talked about?"

[smiling slightly] "Yeah, actually. I took some time for myself this week—went out with a couple of friends, spent more time on photography. It felt good to do something just for me. I’m trying not to feel guilty about it, but I still catch myself worrying about how Jake is handling it."

"That’s great progress, Anna. It’s natural to feel some guilt when you’re shifting focus to yourself, especially after being so used to prioritizing someone else’s needs. How did Jake respond to you taking more time for yourself?"

[sighs] "He didn’t say much, but he’s definitely noticed. He’s been quiet and a little distant, which makes me wonder what’s going on in his head. I’ve been trying not to let it affect me too much, but part of me is worried he’s pulling away because I’ve been pulling away."

"It’s understandable to feel that concern, especially when there’s already some distance in the relationship. How do you feel about the shift in the dynamic? Does Jake pulling away make you feel more uncertain, or are you starting to feel more confident in focusing on yourself?"

"Both, I think. On one hand, it scares me—like, what if we’re drifting apart and this is the beginning of the end? But on the other hand, I’ve been feeling more at peace with myself lately. It’s weird…I don’t feel as desperate to hold onto him as I did before. I still care about him, but I’m starting to realize that I don’t have to lose myself to keep the relationship going."

"That’s a powerful realization, Anna. You’re recognizing that you can care about Jake and still prioritize your own needs. How has this new perspective affected your thoughts about the relationship and whether you want to stay or leave?"

[pauses, thinking] "It’s made me realize that I’m okay on my own. I haven’t decided whether I’m ready to leave yet, but I don’t feel as scared of being alone anymore. I used to think that leaving him would be like losing a part of myself, but now I’m starting to see that I’m still whole, with or without him. But…there’s still that nagging fear about the cheating. I know I need to confront him, but I’m still hesitating."

"It sounds like you’ve made significant progress in finding your own strength, but the infidelity is still weighing on you. What do you think is holding you back from having that conversation with Jake?"

[sighs heavily] "It’s fear of what happens next. If I confront him, there’s no turning back. I don’t know how he’ll react—whether he’ll deny it, admit it, or try to explain it away. And then I’ll have to make a decision, and I’m scared that once I know the truth, I won’t be able to unsee it. I’m not sure if I’m ready for my life to change that much."

"That fear of change is completely understandable. Confronting him could lead to a lot of uncertainty, and it’s natural to feel hesitant about opening that door. What do you think would help you feel more prepared to take that step?"

[pauses, reflecting] "I think I need to be more clear about what I want from the conversation. Right now, I’m just dreading it, but I haven’t really thought about what I hope to get out of it. Do I want closure? Do I want him to apologize? Or do I just want to know the truth so I can move on?"

"That’s a very insightful way to approach it. Knowing what you want from the conversation can help guide how you go into it and how you respond to whatever Jake says. Have you thought about what you need from him to feel like you can move forward, whether that’s in the relationship or on your own?"

"I think I need honesty—no more secrets, no more pretending like everything is fine. If he can’t be honest with me, I don’t see how we can move forward. But I also need him to show me that he’s willing to put in the effort to fix things. I’m not sure if that would be enough to save the relationship, but it’s a start. And if he denies it or gets defensive, I think that would be my answer. I’d have to leave."

"It sounds like honesty and accountability are key for you in deciding what comes next. You’re giving yourself clear criteria for what you need in order to stay, and also recognizing that there’s a limit to what you’re willing to tolerate. How does that feel, knowing you have those boundaries in place?"

[nodding slowly] "It feels…grounding, I guess. Like I have more control than I thought I did. I used to feel like I was just waiting for him to confess or for something to change, but now I see that I have a choice. I can decide what I need, and if he can’t give me that, I can walk away."

"That sense of control is important. You’re no longer just waiting for things to happen—you’re taking an active role in deciding what’s right for you. How do you feel about having that conversation with Jake now that you’ve thought more about what you need from it?"

"I still feel nervous, but I also feel more ready. I know it’s going to be hard, but I can’t keep living like this—carrying this secret and pretending like everything is fine. I think I’m ready to know the truth, even if it hurts."

"It sounds like you’ve reached a point where you’re ready to face the truth, no matter what it is. That’s a huge step, Anna. How do you want to approach the conversation when you’re ready to have it?"

[pauses, thinking deeply] "I think I need to be direct. I’ve been avoiding it for so long, but I can’t dance around it anymore. I’ll tell him that I know about the messages, and I’ll ask him to be honest with me. I don’t want to argue or place blame—I just want to hear the truth from him and decide what to do from there."

"Being direct and clear about what you know and what you need sounds like a strong approach. It gives him the opportunity to respond openly, and it also allows you to stay grounded in what you want from the conversation. How do you think you’ll feel afterward, regardless of how he responds?"

"I think I’ll feel relieved, even if it’s painful. At least I won’t be stuck in this limbo anymore. If he’s honest with me, maybe we can figure out what comes next. If he lies or denies it, then I’ll know that I need to move on. Either way, I’ll finally have some clarity."

"That clarity will be an important part of moving forward, whether it’s rebuilding trust or making the decision to leave. You’ve already come so far in terms of finding your own strength and independence. This conversation is another step toward empowering yourself and taking control of your life. How are you feeling now that you’ve made the decision to confront him?"

[smiling slightly] "I feel more at peace, actually. I’m still scared, but I’m not as overwhelmed as I was before. I think I’m ready to do this. I’m ready to stop pretending and face whatever comes next."

"That’s a huge shift, Anna. You’re moving from a place of uncertainty to one of strength and self-assurance. You’re ready to take control of the situation, and that’s incredibly powerful. How are you planning to prepare for the conversation? Is there anything we can work through here to help you feel more grounded when the time comes?"

"I think I just need to keep reminding myself why I’m doing this—that it’s for me, not for him. I’ve been so worried about protecting his feelings that I forgot about my own. Maybe if I focus on that, I’ll feel more confident when I talk to him."

"That’s a great reminder—this conversation is about your needs and your well-being. It’s about giving yourself the space to heal and move forward, whatever that looks like for you. How are you feeling as we wrap up today’s session?"

"I feel more grounded, like I have a plan. I know it’s going to be hard, but I’m ready to take that step. I’m tired of living with this weight on my shoulders. I want to know the truth and finally move forward."

"You’re doing incredible work, Anna. You’ve made so much progress in reclaiming your sense of self and preparing for what comes next. We’ll continue to support you as you take these steps, and I’m confident that you’ll find the clarity and strength you’re looking for. I’ll see you next week."
"Thanks. See you next week."

This is the sixth therapy session with Anna. She has confronted Jake about his infidelity, and he initially denied it but eventually admitted to cheating. Jake downplayed the affair, calling it a mistake, and apologized, but Anna feels conflicted. She expresses both relief and pain from the conversation, unsure if she can ever trust him again. Anna feels torn between the fear of starting over and the recognition that she is gaining independence and may be okay on her own. The session focuses on her need for honesty and accountability from Jake, while emphasizing her own healing and taking things slowly as she decides the future of the relationship.
"Welcome back, Anna. How are you feeling today? Were you able to have the conversation with Jake?"

[sighs heavily] "Yeah, I did. It was…hard, really hard. But I finally confronted him about the messages. I told him I knew about the cheating. It was like I had been holding my breath for weeks, and now that it’s out there, I feel a mixture of relief and pain."
"That’s a significant step, Anna. How did Jake respond when you brought it up?"

[shakes her head] "At first, he denied it. He acted shocked, like he had no idea what I was talking about. But I stood my ground. I told him I saw the messages with Rachel. That’s when he finally admitted it—he said it was a mistake, that it only happened once, and that it didn’t mean anything. But I don’t know…I don’t know if I believe him."
"That must have been incredibly difficult to hear. How did it feel for you when he finally admitted to the affair?"

[pauses, tearing up] "It hurt, more than I thought it would. I mean, I already knew, but hearing him say it out loud made it real. It’s like all the trust I had in him shattered in that moment. And the worst part is, he kept trying to downplay it, saying it was just one mistake, and that it didn’t mean anything. But how could something like that not mean anything?"
"It’s understandable that you would feel that way. Even if he’s framing it as a mistake, it doesn’t change the impact it has had on you. How did the rest of the conversation go after he admitted it?"

"He kept apologizing, saying he didn’t want to lose me and that he would do anything to make it right. But I just…couldn’t. I told him I needed time, that I wasn’t ready to decide what to do yet. He seemed frustrated, like he wanted to fix it right away, but I just couldn’t give him an answer."

"It sounds like Jake is trying to rush the process, hoping for a quick resolution. But you’re allowed to take your time to figure out what’s right for you. How do you feel now that you’ve had some space since the conversation?"

"I feel conflicted. Part of me feels relieved that it’s finally out in the open, but another part of me is angry—angry that he betrayed me, angry that he thinks one conversation is going to fix everything. I don’t know if I can ever trust him again. But at the same time, I’m scared of starting over. I thought we were building a future together, and now it feels like it’s all fallen apart."

"That conflict you’re feeling makes sense. You’re dealing with both the pain of betrayal and the fear of what comes next, which are two very intense emotions. What do you think you need right now to feel more clear about your next steps?"

[pauses, thinking deeply] "I think I need time. I need to figure out if I can live with this, or if it’s too much to move past. Right now, I can’t even look at him without thinking about what he did. But then I think about how long we’ve been together, all the plans we made, and I wonder if I’m throwing it all away."

"It’s natural to feel torn between the history you’ve built together and the reality of what’s happened. It sounds like you’re giving yourself permission to take the time you need to process everything. Have you thought about what would help you make that decision—whether to stay and work on the relationship or to move on?"

"I think I need to see if he’s really willing to change. If he’s serious about fixing things, maybe there’s a chance. But if he keeps brushing it off or trying to rush me into forgiving him, I don’t think I can stay. I need to feel like he’s taking this seriously, like he understands the depth of what he’s done."

"It sounds like accountability and genuine effort are really important for you in deciding whether to move forward in the relationship. What would Jake need to do for you to feel like he’s truly committed to making things right?"

[pauses, reflecting] "I think he’d need to show me that he’s willing to be open and honest from now on—no more secrets, no more hiding things. He’d also need to give me the space I need to heal, without pressuring me to forgive him right away. And I’d need to see real changes in how he communicates with me. If he can’t do those things, I don’t think I can stay."

"Those are very clear and reasonable expectations, Anna. It’s important that you’re defining what you need in order to feel safe and respected in the relationship. How do you feel about communicating those expectations to Jake?"

"I’m nervous about it. I know he wants things to go back to normal, but things will never be the same again. I’m scared that he’ll say all the right things just to get me to stay, but then nothing will actually change. I guess I’m afraid of giving him another chance and getting hurt all over again."

"That fear of being hurt again is completely valid, especially after such a betrayal. It’s important to trust your instincts and pay attention to whether his actions match his words. What do you think would help you feel more confident in your decision, whether to stay or leave?"

[pauses, considering] "I think I need to take things slow. If I decide to stay, I’ll need to see consistent effort from him over time. Not just a few weeks of good behavior, but real, lasting changes. And if I don’t see that, I think I’ll have my answer. I don’t want to rush into anything just because I’m scared of being alone."

"That’s a very thoughtful approach. Taking things slow gives you the opportunity to observe whether Jake is truly committed to making things right, without feeling pressured to make a quick decision. How do you feel about focusing on your own healing during this time, even as you’re evaluating the relationship?"

"I think that’s what I need to do. I’ve already started taking more time for myself, but I think I need to really focus on my own healing, regardless of what happens with Jake. I don’t want my happiness to be tied to whether or not he changes. I want to feel whole on my own."

"That’s an incredibly powerful realization, Anna. Focusing on your own healing and well-being, independent of what Jake does, puts you in control of your own happiness. What steps do you think you could take to continue nurturing that sense of wholeness for yourself?"

[smiling slightly] "I think I’ll keep doing what I’ve been doing—spending time with friends, getting back into photography, and journaling. I’ve also been thinking about taking a trip by myself, just to clear my head and focus on me for a while. I’ve never done something like that before, but it feels like something I need right now."

"A solo trip sounds like a great way to reconnect with yourself and create space for reflection. It’s a way of showing yourself that you’re capable of finding joy and fulfillment on your own. How does the idea of taking that trip make you feel?"

"Excited, actually. It’s been a long time since I’ve done something just for me. I think it would give me the space I need to really think about what I want, without the pressure of being around Jake all the time."

"That excitement is a great sign that you’re ready to start focusing on yourself more deeply. This trip could be an important part of your healing process, and it gives you time to reflect on your own needs and desires. How do you feel about balancing this focus on yourself with the ongoing situation with Jake?"

"I think I can do both. I don’t want to rush any decisions about the relationship, but I also don’t want to put my own life on hold while I figure things out with him. If he’s serious about fixing things, he’ll understand that I need time and space to heal."

"That balance is key—continuing your own healing journey while also evaluating the relationship on your own terms. It sounds like you’re giving yourself permission to prioritize your well-being, and that’s a huge step forward. How are you feeling as we wrap up today’s session?"

"I feel more at peace, actually. I know I still have a lot to figure out, but I’m not in as much of a rush as I was before. I’m going to focus on myself and take things slow with Jake. If he’s willing to put in the effort, maybe we’ll work through this. But if not, I know I’ll be okay on my own."

"You’re making incredible progress, Anna. You’re reclaiming your sense of self and taking control of your healing process, and that’s something to be proud of. We’ll continue to support you as you navigate this journey, and I’m confident that you’ll find clarity in your own time. I’ll see you next week."
"Thanks. See you next week."

This is the seventh therapy session with Anna. She shares that she has been spending more time on her own, focusing on photography and self-care, but feels stressed by Jake's pressure to move on quickly from the infidelity. Anna expresses frustration that Jake does not seem to fully grasp the depth of her emotional pain. The session focuses on helping Anna clarify her needs—space, time, and genuine effort from Jake to rebuild trust—and her uncertainty about whether to stay in the relationship. The therapist encourages Anna to focus on what she needs for herself, while allowing time to explore her feelings without rushing to a decision.
"Welcome back, Anna. How have things been since our last session? Were you able to make any decisions or reflect more on how you're feeling about the relationship with Jake?"

[sighs] "It’s been a mix of emotions. I’ve been spending more time on my own and focusing on my photography, which has helped me feel more grounded. But Jake has been pushing harder for us to go back to how things were, and it’s stressing me out. I feel like he doesn’t really understand that I need more time. I still haven’t made a decision about whether to stay or leave."

"It sounds like you’re still feeling pressure from Jake to move on quickly, but at the same time, you’re taking important steps to focus on yourself. How has it been for you to take that space and focus on your photography and self-care?"

"It’s been good, actually. It’s given me moments of peace where I don’t feel so overwhelmed by everything. I’ve been meeting up with friends more, too, which has been a nice distraction. But as soon as I’m back with Jake, all the doubts and anger come rushing back. I don’t know if I can ever feel the same about him again."

"That’s understandable, given everything you’ve been through. It sounds like you’ve made some progress in creating space for yourself, but being around Jake is bringing up those unresolved feelings of doubt and anger. Have you expressed to him that you’re still working through those emotions and that you need more time?"

"I have, but he keeps saying that we should just move forward and put it behind us. He doesn’t seem to understand that I can’t just forget what happened. Every time he brushes it off, it makes me more frustrated. I need him to understand how big of a deal this is for me."

"It seems like Jake may not fully grasp the depth of the betrayal and how much it's affecting you. His desire to move on quickly might be coming from his own discomfort, but that doesn’t mean you need to rush your healing. What do you think you need from him in this moment to feel more supported?"

[pauses, thinking] "I think I need him to stop pushing me. I need him to give me space to heal at my own pace. And I need him to show that he’s willing to put in real effort to regain my trust, not just say ‘sorry’ and expect everything to be okay. I’ve told him this, but I don’t know if it’s sinking in."

"It sounds like you’re very clear on what you need from him—space, time, and genuine effort. Have you noticed any changes in his behavior since the confrontation, or does it feel like he’s still expecting things to go back to the way they were without much effort on his part?"

"There have been some changes. He’s been more attentive and apologetic, but it still feels like he’s just going through the motions. Like, he’ll bring me flowers or try to be affectionate, but it feels forced. It’s like he’s doing things he thinks will make me stay, not because he actually understands what I’m going through."

"It sounds like his actions aren’t fully addressing the deeper emotional repair that you need. The gestures might be nice on the surface, but what you’re looking for is a deeper acknowledgment of the hurt and a commitment to rebuilding trust. Do you feel like you’ve been able to communicate that to him?"

"I’ve tried, but I don’t know if he really gets it. I’ve told him that flowers and apologies aren’t enough, that I need more. But I’m starting to wonder if he’s capable of giving me what I need. It’s frustrating because I want to believe he can change, but I don’t see it happening."

"That frustration is completely valid, Anna. It’s difficult when you’ve expressed what you need, but the other person doesn’t seem to fully understand or act on it in a meaningful way. It’s also important to acknowledge that even if Jake is trying, it may not be enough for you to rebuild that trust. How are you feeling about the idea of continuing to stay in the relationship?"

[pauses, sighs heavily] "I’ve been going back and forth. Part of me feels like I owe it to our history to keep trying, but another part of me wonders if I’m just delaying the inevitable. I don’t want to wake up in a year and realize I’ve wasted more time trying to fix something that can’t be fixed. But I also don’t want to give up too soon and regret it later."

"It sounds like you’re weighing the emotional investment you’ve put into the relationship against the possibility that staying might not lead to the change you’re hoping for. It’s a difficult balance to strike. What do you think would help you feel more confident in whichever decision you make?"

"I think I need to stop focusing on what Jake is doing and start focusing on what I need. If I stay, it has to be because I genuinely believe the relationship can heal, not because I’m afraid of leaving or hurting him. And if I leave, I need to feel like I gave it my best shot. But right now, I’m not sure which one is the right choice."

"That’s a very thoughtful way to approach it—focusing on what feels right for you, rather than basing your decision on external pressures or fears. It sounds like you’re close to a point where you’ll know whether staying or leaving is the right choice for you. How do you feel about continuing to take things slowly and allowing yourself more time to explore your feelings?"

"I think I need that. I don’t want to rush into a decision out of fear. I need to give myself the space to really think about what’s best for me, not just for Jake or for the relationship. I’ve been taking things slow already, and I think that’s helping me feel less pressured."

"That’s a very healthy approach, Anna. Giving yourself time and space to fully explore your feelings will allow you to make a decision from a place of clarity, not fear. How are you feeling about the idea of continuing to focus on your personal growth and healing while you navigate these relationship dynamics?"

"It feels good, actually. The more I focus on myself, the less desperate I feel to fix things with Jake. I’m realizing that my happiness doesn’t depend on whether or not the relationship works out. I can be okay on my own, and that’s been a huge shift for me."

"That’s a significant and empowering realization—that your happiness isn’t tied to the outcome of the relationship. You’re taking control of your own well-being, which is a huge step forward. What do you think would be helpful for you to continue nurturing that sense of independence and self-care?"

"I think I need to keep doing what I’ve been doing—spending time with friends, focusing on photography, and journaling. The solo trip I mentioned last time is still on my mind, and I think I’m ready to book it. It would give me some distance from Jake and a chance to really focus on myself."

"A solo trip sounds like a wonderful opportunity for reflection and self-care. It gives you the chance to step away from the relationship dynamics for a while and focus entirely on yourself. How do you feel about taking that trip and the kind of clarity it might bring you?"

"I’m excited about it. It’s something I’ve never done before, and I think it’ll give me the space I need to clear my head. I’m hoping that being away from Jake for a while will help me figure out what I really want, without feeling his presence or pressure."

"That space could be incredibly valuable for you, Anna. It will give you time to focus on your needs and desires, and it might help you gain even more clarity about the future of the relationship. How do you feel about preparing for that trip and using it as a tool for your personal growth?"

"I feel ready for it. I think it’ll be a turning point for me, whether I decide to stay or leave. It’ll be a chance to reconnect with myself and figure out what I want moving forward. I’m nervous, but I also feel like it’s the right thing to do."

"That’s a great perspective to have—seeing the trip as a turning point and an opportunity to reconnect with yourself. It sounds like you’re in a strong place to take this next step. How are you feeling as we wrap up today’s session?"

"I feel more settled. I’m not as anxious as I was before, and I’m starting to feel more confident in my ability to handle whatever comes next. I’m going to focus on myself for now and take the trip as a chance to get some distance and clarity."

"You’re making incredible progress, Anna. You’re taking control of your own journey, and you’re giving yourself the time and space you need to heal and grow. We’ll continue to support you through this process, and I’m excited to hear about how the trip goes. I’ll see you next week."
"Thanks. See you next week."

This is the eighth therapy session with Anna. She has booked her solo trip and feels a mix of excitement and nervousness, knowing it will provide much-needed space to reflect on her relationship with Jake. Jake is not happy about the trip, but Anna remains firm in her decision to take time for herself. The session focuses on Anna’s anticipation of the trip and her hopes for gaining clarity about whether to stay or leave the relationship. The therapist helps Anna prepare to use the time away to focus on self-care, reflection, and reconnection with her own needs.
"Welcome back, Anna. How are you feeling today? Did you make any progress on your plans for the solo trip, or have any new reflections about your situation with Jake?"

[smiling slightly] "I actually did it—I booked the trip. I leave in a couple of days, and I’m really excited, but also a little nervous. It feels like a big step. I’ve never done anything like this before, but I think it’s what I need right now. Jake wasn’t too happy about it, though."
"That’s a huge step, Anna. I’m really glad you decided to take the trip. How did Jake react when you told him?"

"He didn’t take it well at first. He kept asking why I needed to go away and why I couldn’t just work through things with him here. I tried to explain that I needed some space to clear my head, but he was frustrated. He eventually said he’d support whatever I needed, but I could tell he wasn’t happy about it."

"It sounds like Jake is struggling with the idea of you taking space, but it’s great that you were able to explain your needs and stick to them, even if it made him uncomfortable. How are you feeling about the trip now that it’s just a few days away?"

[pauses, thinking] "I feel a mix of things. I’m excited to get away and have time to myself, but there’s also a part of me that’s anxious—what if I come back and everything’s even worse? Or what if I realize I don’t want to be with Jake anymore? It feels like this trip could be a turning point, but I don’t know which way it’ll go."

"It’s completely natural to feel both excited and anxious. This trip represents a lot of possibilities for you—space for reflection, clarity about what you want, and maybe even the chance to come back with a renewed sense of direction. What do you hope to gain from the time away?"

"I think I just need to clear my mind. I’ve been so caught up in the emotions of the situation with Jake that I haven’t had much time to really think about what I want. I want to spend time focusing on myself, without the pressure of being around him and feeling like I have to make a decision right away. I’m hoping that the distance will give me some perspective."

"That sounds like a really healthy approach. Giving yourself the chance to focus on your own needs, without the immediate pressure of the relationship, could help you gain the clarity you’re looking for. How do you plan to spend your time on the trip? Do you have any activities or plans in mind?"

[smiling softly] "I’m planning to do a lot of hiking. The place I’m going is near the mountains, and I’ve always loved being in nature. I’m bringing my camera, too—I figured this would be a good chance to get back into photography. Other than that, I just want to relax, read, and journal. I don’t want to fill up my time with too many plans. I really want to take it slow and just…breathe."

"That sounds like a beautiful way to spend the trip—giving yourself the time and space to connect with nature, do the things you love, and reflect on your feelings. How do you think it’ll feel to be away from Jake during this time? Do you think the distance will help you gain clarity about the relationship?"

"I think so. It’s been hard to think clearly when I’m around him, especially with the pressure he’s been putting on me to move forward. I’m hoping that being away from him will give me some space to figure out what I really want—whether that’s working on the relationship or moving on. I’ve been feeling less scared about being on my own lately, but I still haven’t made up my mind."

"It sounds like the distance could provide you with a sense of freedom to explore your feelings without the immediate influence of the relationship. How are you feeling about the idea that this trip might help you make a decision, one way or another?"

[pauses, reflecting deeply] "I’m ready for that, I think. I’ve been putting off making a decision because I’ve been so scared of what it’ll mean, but I can’t keep living in limbo. If I come back and realize that I can’t move past the betrayal, then I’ll know what I have to do. And if I feel like there’s still something worth saving, then I’ll be willing to give it another shot. But either way, I need to stop avoiding the decision."

"That’s a very grounded and thoughtful approach, Anna. You’re giving yourself permission to take the time you need, but you’re also recognizing that clarity will come from allowing yourself to fully reflect on what’s right for you. How do you plan to approach the decision when you come back? What signs or feelings will help guide you toward the right choice?"

"I think I’ll need to pay attention to how I feel when I’m away—whether I feel more peaceful without Jake or whether I miss him in a way that makes me want to try again. I’ll also need to see how he behaves while I’m gone. If he respects my space and gives me the time I need, that’ll show me that he’s serious about changing. But if he keeps pushing or trying to control the situation, I’ll know that he hasn’t really changed."

"That’s a great strategy—focusing on both your own feelings and how Jake responds during this time. You’ve already done so much work in identifying what you need in order to feel safe and respected in the relationship. This trip could be an opportunity to see how those needs align with what Jake is offering and how you feel about the possibility of moving forward with or without him."

"Yeah, that’s what I’m hoping for. I want to come back with a clearer idea of what I want, even if that means making a hard decision. I know it’s not going to be easy, but I feel more ready to face it now than I did before."

"You’ve made incredible progress, Anna. You’ve moved from a place of fear and uncertainty to a place where you’re feeling more empowered and in control of your own journey. This trip sounds like it will be a powerful experience for you, and I’m confident that you’ll come back with more clarity. How are you feeling about preparing for the trip and setting your intentions for what you want to get out of it?"

[smiling slightly] "I feel ready. I’ve already packed most of my things, and I’ve been journaling about what I hope to gain from the experience. I’m trying not to put too much pressure on myself, though—I want to let things unfold naturally and see where it leads me."

"That’s a great mindset to have—allowing yourself to be open to whatever the experience brings, without putting too much pressure on the outcome. It’s about giving yourself the freedom to explore and reflect. How are you feeling as we wrap up today’s session and prepare for this next step?"

"I feel good, actually. I’m excited for the trip, and I’m ready to give myself the space to figure things out. I know I still have a lot to work through, but I feel more at peace with the process. I’ll just take it one day at a time and see what happens."

"That sounds like a very healthy approach, Anna. You’re in a great place to take this time for yourself and see where it leads. We’ll continue to support you through this process, and I’m looking forward to hearing how the trip goes. I’ll see you when you get back."
"Thanks. See you after the trip."

This is the ninth therapy session with Anna. She returns from her solo trip, feeling more peaceful and grounded. During the trip, Anna realized that she has been holding onto her relationship with Jake out of fear of being alone, but now feels more at peace with the idea of moving on. She expresses readiness to let go of the relationship, realizing that staying is prolonging her pain. The session centers on helping Anna prepare to have the conversation with Jake about ending the relationship, approaching it from a place of honesty and acceptance. The therapist supports Anna in planning for the emotional aftermath and continuing her focus on self-care.
"Welcome back, Anna. How was your trip? Did it help bring you any clarity or peace about your situation?"

[smiling slightly] "The trip was amazing. It was exactly what I needed. I spent a lot of time hiking, journaling, and just being with my thoughts. There were moments where I felt more peaceful than I have in a long time. It gave me the space to really think about what I want and what I need moving forward."
"That’s wonderful to hear. It sounds like the trip gave you the time and distance you needed to reflect. What realizations or thoughts came up for you during your time away?"

[pauses, reflecting] "I realized that I’ve been holding onto the relationship with Jake out of fear—fear of being alone, fear of starting over. But when I was away from him, I started to feel more at peace with the idea of moving on. I didn’t miss him the way I thought I would. Instead, I felt more relieved, like I was finally free from all the pressure and anxiety."

"That’s a powerful realization. It sounds like being away from Jake helped you see that your fear of being alone was keeping you in a situation that wasn’t bringing you peace. How are you feeling now about the idea of moving on from the relationship?"

"I think I’m ready to let go. During the trip, I had a lot of time to think about what I want for myself, and I realized that I don’t want to keep living in a relationship where I don’t feel safe or fully trust him. I’ve been putting off the decision because I didn’t want to face the pain of ending it, but now I see that staying is just prolonging that pain."
"That’s a huge shift, Anna. You’ve gone from feeling stuck and unsure to feeling more confident in your ability to move forward on your own. What has helped you feel ready to let go?"

[sighs, smiling softly] "I think it’s because I finally gave myself permission to imagine a life without Jake. I realized that I can be happy on my own, that I don’t need the relationship to feel whole. I reconnected with parts of myself that I had lost, like my love for photography and my independence. It made me see that I’ve been holding myself back by staying in a relationship that no longer serves me."

"It sounds like the trip gave you the space to reconnect with yourself and see that you are capable of thriving on your own. How do you feel now about the prospect of having that conversation with Jake—telling him that you’ve decided to end the relationship?"

[pauses, takes a deep breath] "I’m nervous, of course. I know it’s going to be hard, but I also feel ready. I’ve been avoiding it for so long, but now I see that it’s the only way for me to fully move forward. I’m not angry anymore—I just want to be honest with him and tell him that it’s time for both of us to let go."

"It sounds like you’ve reached a place of acceptance, where you’re ready to have that difficult conversation from a place of peace rather than anger. How do you think Jake will react when you tell him?"

"I think he’ll be upset. He’s been trying so hard to fix things, even though I don’t think he fully understands what I need. But I also think he knows that something has been off between us for a while. I just hope he can accept it and not try to convince me to stay."
"It’s understandable that you’re concerned about how Jake might react, but it sounds like you’re feeling strong in your decision. How do you want to approach the conversation with him?"

[pauses, thinking deeply] "I want to be clear and honest. I don’t want it to turn into a fight or a blame game. I’ll tell him that I’ve spent a lot of time reflecting and that I’ve realized we’re not right for each other anymore. I’ll explain that I need to move on for my own well-being and that it’s not about him being a bad person—it’s just that the relationship doesn’t work for me anymore."

"That sounds like a thoughtful and respectful approach. You’re giving yourself the space to be honest without placing blame, and you’re staying focused on what’s best for you. How do you think you’ll feel after the conversation, once you’ve had the chance to express your decision?"

"I think I’ll feel relieved. It’s been hanging over my head for so long, and I’ve been carrying this weight of indecision. Once I say it out loud, I think I’ll finally feel free to start the next chapter of my life."

"That sense of relief will likely be a big part of your healing process. You’ve already done so much work in reconnecting with yourself and finding your independence. This conversation is another step toward fully reclaiming your life. How are you feeling about the idea of starting over, now that you’ve had time to think about it?"

[smiling softly] "I’m not as scared as I was before. The trip showed me that I can be happy on my own, that I can create a life for myself that feels fulfilling. I’m not saying it won’t be hard, but I’m ready to embrace the uncertainty and see where it takes me. I feel like I’m rediscovering parts of myself that I had forgotten about, and that’s exciting."

"It’s so encouraging to hear that, Anna. You’re embracing the idea of starting over with a sense of curiosity and excitement, rather than fear. That’s a testament to how much growth you’ve experienced in this process. How do you plan to take care of yourself in the days following the conversation with Jake, regardless of how it goes?"

"I’ve been thinking about that. I know it’s going to be emotional, so I’ve planned to spend some time with friends afterward. I don’t want to be alone that night. I’ve also decided to keep up with my journaling and photography—those have been really grounding for me. I’m going to focus on creating new routines that are just for me."

"That sounds like a great plan, Anna. Surrounding yourself with support and continuing to engage in the activities that bring you joy will help you stay grounded during this transition. How are you feeling now that you’ve talked through everything and made the decision to move forward?"

"I feel calm, actually. There’s still some nervousness, but I don’t feel as overwhelmed as I did before. I know what I need to do, and I’m ready to take that step. I just want to move forward and start living for myself again."

"You’ve come such a long way, Anna. Your clarity and sense of peace are a reflection of all the work you’ve done to focus on your own growth and well-being. You’re ready to take this next step, and we’ll continue to support you through the process. I’ll see you after the conversation with Jake, and we can talk about how you’re feeling then."
"Thank you. I feel ready, and I’m grateful for the support. I’ll let you know how it goes."

This is the tenth therapy session with Anna. She shares that she has finally ended her relationship with Jake after a calm and reflective conversation. Anna expresses a sense of relief, mixed with sadness, but feels that she made the right decision. The session focuses on her processing the breakup, leaning on her support system, and finding excitement in setting new personal goals, such as taking a photography class and planning a solo trip. Anna is starting to embrace the idea of focusing on herself and her own happiness, rather than a relationship.
"Welcome back, Anna. I know this was a big week for you. How did the conversation with Jake go? How are you feeling now?"

[sighs softly] "It was tough, but I finally had the conversation. I told him that I had spent a lot of time reflecting and that I couldn’t stay in the relationship anymore. He was upset, as I expected, but he didn’t fight me on it. He tried to convince me to stay at first, saying that he’d do anything to make it right, but I told him that I had made up my mind. After a while, he accepted it."
"It sounds like you were very clear and direct with him, and you stayed strong in your decision. How did you feel during the conversation?"

"I was nervous at first, but once I started talking, I felt a sense of calm. I thought I’d feel more emotional, but I didn’t. I think it’s because I had already processed so much of it during the trip and in our sessions. By the time I said it out loud, I knew it was the right decision for me."

"That’s an important realization. You were able to approach the conversation from a place of peace and certainty, which reflects how much work you’ve done to prepare for this moment. How has it been for you since the conversation? What emotions have come up?"

[pauses, thinking] "There’s been some sadness, of course. I spent four years with Jake, and it’s hard to let go of all the memories and the future we thought we were building together. But I also feel…relieved. Like a weight has been lifted. I don’t feel stuck anymore. I know it’s going to take time to fully move on, but I’m not scared of that anymore."

"It sounds like you’re feeling a healthy mix of emotions—acknowledging the sadness of the end of a relationship, but also recognizing the relief and freedom that comes with moving forward. How have you been taking care of yourself since the breakup?"

"I’ve been leaning on my friends a lot. After the conversation, I spent the evening with one of my closest friends, and it really helped to have someone there to talk to. I’ve also been journaling, like we discussed, and I’ve been going out with my camera again. It feels good to have these outlets, but there are still moments where I feel a little lost."

"That’s completely normal, Anna. Ending a long-term relationship brings up a lot of different emotions, and even though you feel relief, it’s natural to have moments where you feel a sense of loss or uncertainty. You’ve done an excellent job of creating a support system for yourself and using your passions to stay grounded. What do you think you need right now to continue processing these feelings?"

"I think I just need time. I’m not in a rush to feel 100% okay, but I do want to keep moving forward. I’ve been thinking about setting some new goals for myself, things that are just for me. Maybe take a photography class, or even start planning a solo trip abroad at some point."

"Those sound like great ways to continue focusing on your personal growth and healing. Setting new goals and engaging in activities that bring you joy can help you stay connected to your sense of independence and fulfillment. How do you feel about the idea of exploring these goals as part of your next steps?"

[smiling slightly] "It feels exciting, actually. I haven’t thought about myself like this in a long time—what I want, what makes me happy. I used to be so focused on Jake and the relationship, but now I can put all that energy back into myself. It’s a little scary to think about starting over, but it also feels like a new beginning."

"That’s a wonderful mindset to have—seeing this as a new beginning, a chance to reconnect with what makes you feel fulfilled and whole. It sounds like you’re approaching this next chapter with both excitement and curiosity. What do you think will be most important for you as you continue on this path of self-discovery?"

"I think I need to keep reminding myself that it’s okay to put myself first. I’ve spent so much time trying to make the relationship work that I forgot what it feels like to focus on my own needs. I want to stay mindful of that and make sure I don’t lose sight of myself again, no matter what happens."

"That’s a great intention, Anna—prioritizing yourself and staying mindful of your needs is key to continuing your growth. It’s also important to remember that this is a process, and there may be ups and downs along the way. How are you feeling about the future, both in terms of your personal growth and your emotional healing?"

"I feel optimistic. I know it won’t always be easy, but I finally feel like I’m on the right path. I’m starting to trust myself more, and that’s helping me feel more confident in what’s ahead. I don’t have everything figured out, but I’m okay with that. I’ll just take it one step at a time."

"That’s a very healthy perspective—to trust yourself and take things one step at a time. You’ve already made so much progress in finding your independence and reconnecting with yourself. As we move forward, we can continue exploring ways to support your personal goals and emotional healing. How are you feeling as we wrap up today’s session?"

"I feel good, actually. I’m proud of how far I’ve come, and I feel more at peace with the breakup. I know it’ll take time to fully heal, but I’m not in a rush. I’m just going to keep focusing on myself and see where that takes me."

"You should be proud, Anna. You’ve done incredible work in prioritizing your own growth and well-being, and you’ve come a long way since our first session. We’ll continue to support you as you take these next steps. I’ll see you next week."
"Thanks. See you next week."

This is the eleventh therapy session with Anna. She discusses how she has been feeling since the breakup and reflects on her personal growth. Anna has taken up a photography class and gone on solo photo walks, reconnecting with her creativity. She expresses a newfound sense of freedom and independence, enjoying the present and no longer dwelling on the past. The session highlights Anna's shift toward self-discovery, as she feels more secure in being on her own and is planning another solo trip. She also notes that she is not in a rush to date again, focusing instead on her own growth and fulfillment.
"Welcome back, Anna. It’s been a little while since our last session. How have you been feeling as you continue to navigate the breakup and focus on yourself?"

[smiling softly] "I’ve been doing well, actually. It hasn’t been easy, but I feel like I’m in a better place now. There are moments when I still feel sad about the end of the relationship, but those moments are becoming less frequent. I’ve been spending more time with friends, and I signed up for a photography class like we talked about. It’s been really fun to focus on something just for me."

"It sounds like you’re making great progress in finding fulfillment outside of the relationship. That’s a big step forward, especially now that you’re channeling your energy into things that bring you joy. How has the photography class been so far?"

"It’s been really exciting! I almost forgot how much I love photography. The class has been helping me get back into the creative mindset, and I’m learning new techniques that I never thought to try before. I even went on a little solo photo walk around the city last weekend, just capturing things that caught my eye. It felt so freeing."

"That sounds like a wonderful way to reconnect with yourself and express your creativity. It seems like you’re finding new ways to explore your independence and rediscover what makes you feel fulfilled. How have you been feeling emotionally during these moments of creativity and independence?"

[pauses, reflecting] "Honestly, I feel more alive. There’s a sense of freedom that I haven’t felt in a long time. I don’t feel as weighed down by the sadness of the breakup as I did before. I’ve been more focused on the present—on enjoying my time, rather than worrying about the past or the future. It’s like I’m finally letting go of the heaviness I carried for so long."

"That’s a beautiful shift, Anna. It sounds like you’re really embracing the present and allowing yourself to feel lighter, both emotionally and creatively. How do you think this new focus on the present has affected your overall sense of well-being?"

"It’s made a huge difference. I used to spend so much time dwelling on the past, on what I could’ve done differently, or worrying about the future—whether I’d ever find happiness again. But now, I’m just taking things day by day, and it’s been so refreshing. I don’t feel like I’m chasing something anymore; I’m just…living."

"It’s clear that this new approach has brought you a sense of peace. You’re no longer feeling the pressure to force happiness or chase after a specific outcome, which is a big part of finding true fulfillment. How do you think you’ll continue to nurture this sense of being present as you move forward?"

"I think I’ll keep focusing on the things that make me feel grounded—photography, journaling, spending time with friends. I’m also planning another solo trip, maybe to a new city this time. I want to keep exploring, not just new places, but also new aspects of myself. I feel like there’s so much more to discover now that I’m not tied to the relationship."

"That’s an exciting plan. Continuing to explore both your inner world and the world around you will help you deepen this connection with yourself. What do you think has been the most surprising realization you’ve had since the breakup and through this process of self-discovery?"

[pauses, smiling thoughtfully] "I think the most surprising thing is how okay I am being on my own. I always thought I needed someone else to feel complete, but I’ve realized that I’m already whole. It’s been eye-opening to see that I don’t need a relationship to feel happy or secure. I’m enjoying my own company more than I ever thought I would."

"That’s such a powerful realization, Anna—knowing that you’re whole on your own and don’t need external validation to feel complete. It’s a big shift from where you were at the beginning of this journey. How do you think this newfound sense of independence will influence your future relationships, if and when you decide to pursue them?"

"I’ve thought about that a lot. I don’t think I’m ready to date again just yet, but when I do, I know I’ll approach it differently. I won’t be looking for someone to ‘complete’ me—I’ll be looking for someone who complements the life I’ve already built for myself. And I won’t be afraid to set boundaries or walk away if the relationship isn’t right. I’ve learned that it’s okay to put myself first."

"It sounds like you’ve gained a lot of wisdom from this experience. You’re approaching the idea of future relationships with clarity and self-respect, which will help you build healthier connections when the time is right. How do you feel about the possibility of dating again in the future, even though it’s not something you’re actively pursuing right now?"

"I feel open to it, but I’m not in any rush. I’ve realized that being single is a perfectly valid and fulfilling option, and I’m happy where I am right now. I want to keep focusing on my own growth, and if the right person comes along, great—but if not, I’m okay with that too. I’ve stopped putting so much pressure on myself to follow a certain timeline or meet certain expectations."

"That openness and flexibility will serve you well, both in your personal life and in any future relationships. You’re allowing yourself to grow at your own pace, without feeling confined by external pressures. Have you noticed any changes in how your friends or family are reacting to this new chapter in your life?"

[laughs softly] "Yeah, my friends have definitely noticed. They’ve been really supportive, telling me how proud they are of how I’ve handled everything. I think they were a little worried about me at first, but now they can see that I’m thriving. My mom has been especially encouraging—she’s always telling me how strong I am and how she’s happy to see me focusing on myself."

"It’s wonderful that you have such a strong support system and that your friends and family are recognizing the positive changes in you. It sounds like they’re helping reinforce the growth you’ve experienced. How does it feel to have that external validation, even though you’re already secure in your own self-worth?"

"It feels good. I don’t need their validation to feel secure, but it’s nice to know that the people who care about me see the changes I’ve made. It’s like they’re reflecting back what I’ve been feeling inside—more confident, more independent. It feels like I’m on the right path."

"That’s a great balance—appreciating the external validation but staying grounded in your own sense of self-worth. You’ve come a long way in recognizing your own value and taking ownership of your journey. What do you see as your next steps in continuing this path of self-discovery and independence?"

"I want to keep building on what I’ve started. I’m really enjoying the photography class, so I want to dive deeper into that and maybe start sharing my work more. I’ve also been thinking about picking up another hobby, maybe something like painting or yoga—something that helps me stay connected to myself. And of course, there’s the solo trip I mentioned. I’m still figuring out where I want to go, but I think it’ll be another chance to explore both the world and myself."

"Those all sound like wonderful goals, Anna. Exploring new hobbies and continuing to travel will help you stay grounded in your sense of independence and creativity. How are you feeling about the idea of continuing to prioritize yourself, even as you navigate the possibility of future relationships or other life changes?"

"I feel confident about it. I know that no matter what happens, whether I end up in another relationship or not, I’ll never lose sight of myself again. This whole experience has taught me that my happiness and fulfillment come from within, and that’s something I’m not willing to compromise anymore."

"That’s a strong and empowering mindset, Anna. You’re committed to maintaining your sense of self no matter what life brings, and that’s a huge shift from where you were when we first started. How do you feel as you look back on the journey you’ve been on since the breakup?"

[pauses, smiling softly] "It’s kind of surreal. I remember feeling so lost and scared in the beginning, like I didn’t know how I’d ever move forward. But now, looking back, I’m proud of how far I’ve come. I’ve learned so much about myself, and I’ve grown in ways I never expected. I feel more grounded and confident than I ever have before."

"You’ve made incredible progress, Anna. It’s clear that you’ve not only healed from the breakup but also discovered a deeper sense of self along the way. How are you feeling as we wrap up today’s session and look ahead to the future?"

"I feel excited, honestly. I’m looking forward to whatever comes next, whether that’s new hobbies, new experiences, or just continuing to grow on my own. I’m not in a rush to figure everything out—I’m just enjoying the process."

"That’s a beautiful place to be—enjoying the process of growth and embracing the unknown with excitement rather than fear. You’ve reached a point where you’re not only healing but thriving in ways you hadn’t expected. It sounds like you’re truly in tune with yourself."

"Yeah, it feels that way. I’m not afraid of what’s next anymore. I’ve learned that I can handle whatever comes my way, and that’s been really empowering. I’m excited about continuing this journey of self-discovery."

"That sense of self-assurance is one of the most valuable things you’ve gained from this process. As we wrap up today’s session, what’s one thing you’d like to carry forward into the next phase of your life?"

[pauses, reflecting] "I think I want to carry forward the idea that I’m enough on my own. That no matter what happens—whether I’m in a relationship or not, whether life goes exactly as planned or takes an unexpected turn—I’m whole, and I’m capable of finding happiness within myself."

"That’s a powerful realization, Anna. You’re in control of your happiness and fulfillment, and that inner strength will carry you forward in whatever direction life takes. I’m confident that you’ll continue to grow and thrive as you explore this next chapter."
"Thank you. It feels good to finally be in this place. I’m really grateful for all the support during this process."

"You’ve done incredible work, Anna. You’ve been committed to your growth, and it’s been inspiring to see how far you’ve come. I’ll see you next week, and we’ll continue to support you as you navigate whatever comes next."
"Thanks. See you next week."

"It’s been really empowering. I’m starting to see myself in a different light, like I’m more than just the person who went through a breakup.
